page.title: 02The River Avon.
page.content: {The River Avon}is quite deep. However, the weed interferes with the flow of the river. People cut the weed - the cutting starts in April. In the old days, knives were used to cut the weed which sometimes grew to a length of three or four feet. The longest recorded length of weed in the Avon is twenty-five feet. Nowadays, the cutting service uses boats with weed or grass cutters on them. This new service started round about 1940. When the weed has been cut, a weed boom is laid across the river. A weed boom is a rake which catches the weed as the river flows. All the land on both sides of the river is private, apart from the stretch at the recreation ground in Fordingbridge.
